title: Examples of Baskerville
content:
Fellow Typophiles,

I am looking for examples of Baskerville in use: posters, ads, logos, book covers...

Any help appreciated.

dr

 [‹ Harvard Business Review](http://web.archive.org/web/20080708215401/http:/www.typophile.com/node/44745 "Go to previous forum topic") [Anti-aliased Vs. Aliased type for HTML type in screenshots?? Help.. ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080708215401/http:/www.typophile.com/node/44742 "Go to next forum topic")
author: David R

comments.content: [Stephenson Blake Baskerville Old Face, ITC New Baskerville](http://web.archive.org/web/20080708215401/http:/img137.imageshack.us/img137/7367/gobletcovfk9.png)

thank you very much,

dr

ps: adelphi logo is unfortunately way too small to be used, and I couldnt find it in a good resolution...

[http://cgi.ebay.com/Fortune-Magazine-March-1930-Wall-Street-Map-Hemingwa...](http://web.archive.org/web/20080708215401/http:/cgi.ebay.com/Fortune-Magazine-March-1930-Wall-Street-Map-Hemingway_W0QQitemZ320237893024QQcmdZViewItem "http://cgi.ebay.com/Fortune-Magazine-March-1930-Wall-Street-Map-Hemingway\_W0QQitemZ320237893024QQcmdZViewItem")

The entire editorial matter of _Fortune_ (during the 1930s) was set in Baskerville—headlines, captions, text; some on laid paper, some on coated. They were magnificent publications.
